title: Blockade IMARC: Third day of Melbourne protest
text:
Tensions between climate change protesters and police have erupted outside a mining conference in Melbourne.

Mass arrests and hospitalisations continue as protesters and police clash in Melbourne

Climate change activists back on the front line outside a global mining conference in Melbourne have labelled police actions “vicious” and of a never-before-seen level of aggression.

“I’ve been an activist for many years,” protester Emma Black told Seven this morning.

“I haven’t seen this kind of aggression before.”

Ms Black said she was hit with a baton on Tuesday “when trying to comply with police instructions” and claimed the officer who repeatedly struck her was “told off” by a colleague.

She said they were liberally covered in capsicum spray while trying to shut down the three-day International Mining and Resources Conference.

“We have repeatedly said every day today and every interview that we support a sustainable transition to green jobs,” Ms Black said.

“That is what we’re here for, that is what we are fighting for. These companies are not engaging in that transition right now. We want to put pressure on them to do exactly that.”

Ms Black said protesters would have more to say in coming days “about the vicious actions of police”.

About 100 demonstrators gathered outside the Convention and Exhibition Centre on Thursday.

Police have warned they’ll respond if protesters continue trying to block delegates from entering. Officers have frequently used capsicum spray to break up the crowds.

About 300 protesters tried to block access and some glued themselves to the ground or shimmied up poles on Wednesday.

Members of the media are again being asked by police to be mindful of their surroundings as the nature of the protest becomes “very dynamic”.

Channel 7 journalist Paul Dowsley was “stunned” after being grabbed and pushed around by officers yesterday.

Police said the activists’ tactics had escalated since the conference began on Tuesday.

So far this week, police have arrested more than 60 protesters on various offences, including 17 on Wednesday and more than 50 on Tuesday.

A GoFundMe page set up protest organisers to pay for legal cost has so far raised more than $14,500.

Victoria Police said its officers are doing their job in a “measured” way.

At least two protesters made it inside the meeting, with one storming the stage before being removed.

The protest will wrap-up on Thursday ahead of an Extinction Rebellion Youth-led march in the CBD from 10am and another rally in the evening.

A conference organiser said security coverage for the three-day meeting is “constantly being updated as we take advice from Victoria Police”.

– with AAP
description: Climate change activists back on the front line outside a global mining conference in Melbourne have labelled police actions “vicious” and of a never-before-seen level of aggression.
